author: Helen Pickles
title: The 5 best family days out from Newcastle
text: Follow the links below to see the rest of our guide • The best family days out from Manchester • The best family days out from Birmingham • The best family days out from Bristol • The best family days out from London Alnwick Castle Go back in time at the Duke of Northumberland’s castle, 45 minutes’ drive north of Newcastle, just off the A1. Don your knight or princess outfit – costumes available – and try your hand at a medieval craft, such as making soap or tiles, with resident artisans. There are sword-fighting lessons, too. Elsewhere, learn how to fly on a broomstick in the spot where Harry Potter first took flight and, for the over-nines, pick up some archery skills (for an extra £3). 01665 511100; alnwickcastle.com ; adult £14, child (5-16) £7.20, family £37.05 (5 per cent discount if you book online). Go back in time at the Duke of Northumberland’s castle, 45 minutes’ drive north of Newcastle Photo: AP/FOTOLIA Go Ape! Matfen Set in the grounds of Matfen Hall, near Hexham, this half-mile treetop adventure course guarantees high levels of action. Expect wobbly bridges, awkward tunnels, moving hoops, Tarzan ropes and a 160-metre zip-wire ride to bring you swooshing down to earth. Children must be over 10 years and 4ft 7in (1.4m) tall. 0333 331 7583; goape.co.uk adult £31, child (ages 10-15) £25. • 50 great days out in the UK • Holiday complaints: what to do when things go wrong • How to survive a long car journey with children Low Newton-by-the-Sea beach and walk Just north of Alnwick is one of the prettiest beaches on the Northumberland coast. The curved stretch of sand makes a lovely flat spot for beach cricket and rounders. When the tide is out, go rock-pooling for limpets, crabs and starfish. Have lunch at The Ship Inn, in the village, then set off on the Newton Pool coastal walk – with its two bird hides, it offers a good introduction to birdwatching. nationaltrust. org.uk View from Low Newton-by-the-Sea to Dunstanburgh Castle Photo: Alamy Cragside Just three-quarters of an hour’s drive north west of Newcastle, you can lose the grown-ups in the labyrinth, part of the 1,000-acre woodland and gardens surrounding the imposing home of the Victorian engineer Lord Armstrong. Look for surprises along the way, such as William the Wizard and the Storyteller’s Chair. In the centre is a giant, interactive musical box; turn a handle, pedal a bike and wonderful things happen. Under-12s should download the National Trust’s “50 things to do before you’re 11¾” challenge. Some of these – build a den, take a barefoot walk – can be done here. 01669 620333; nationaltrust.org ; adult £10.70, child £5.40, family £25.50; 50things.org.uk . • The 20 best hidden beaches in the UK • How to survive a family trip to the zoo • Flying with children: 10 secrets to stress-free travel Derwent reservoir Derwent reservoir, half an hour’s drive south west of Newcastle, runs “Try it” days for the family to try fly-fishing or fishing with bait. Learn how to cast, then hook, play and land a trout. Pack a picnic and keep an eye out for buzzards, red kite, ospreys, and red squirrels, too. 01207 255250; nwl.co.uk ; adult £30, child £15.
